channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 31
item.description: (The Cut)  Read: The therapy-app fantasy. The US and 13 other countries have also bashed the report, which concluded that bat → another animal → humans was the likeliest cause of the initial outbreak.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Reader Q&A: What Is Financial Leverage?
item.description: The idea is to borrow money to make purchases that, over time, can make you far more money than your initial capital could.  In the financial world, investors use the term "leverage" to refer to debt that's used to fund transactions. But while leverage can increase your reward, it can also increase risk, which is where the story of this hedge fund, Archegos Capital Management, comes in.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Amazon Unionization Vote: Here's What to Watch
item.description: There's a close race to follow in Bessemer, AL, that decides whether or not 6,000 Amazon warehouse workers unionize. Union organizers may bring up Amazon's anti-union messaging campaign at the warehouse, which even followed workers into the bathroom. Plus, workers already get healthcare, vision, and dental benefits without paying union dues.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: US Home Prices Hit 7-Year High
item.description: Some experts think rising mortgage rates could cool the market. But as the pool of would-be buyers has grown, supply's gotten tighter than a Lower East Side kitchen: In February, available homes fell nearly a third to just over 1 million.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Key Performance Indicators
item.description: (Engelsberg Ideas)  Read: The geopolitical fight to come over green energy.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Massive Container Ship Ever Given Still Stuck in the Suez Canal
item.description: But that's like driving from New York to Philadelphia via Calgary: It adds 6,000 miles and $300,000 in fuel costs to the journey.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Bank of England Reveals New £50 Banknote Honoring Alan Turing
item.description: The banknote includes an image of Turing, one of his quotes, and lots of nerdy Easter eggs such as a string of ticker tape displaying Turing's birthday in binary code.   In his work solving Enigma, he came up with the "Turing bombe," a precursor to the modern computer.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: H&M, Nike Face Backlash in China
item.description: Ex.: Last September, H&M released a statement saying it was concerned about allegations of forced labor in Xinjiang, a Chinese territory that produces an estimated 20% of the world’s cotton. State media outlets called out other apparel brands, including Nike and Adidas, that've made statements about boycotting Xinjiang cotton. And celebrities including Wang Yibo and Victoria Song are dropping H&M and/or Nike endorsements.   On Tuesday, a human rights group coalition sent a letter to Airbnb asking it to pull out, questioning the company's commitment to "social responsibility."
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Darden Restaurants is Raising Wages as a Sign of Sales
item.description: At one point during the pandemic, same-store sales at Darden restaurants dropped 75%. Darden Restaurants, the parent company of Olive Garden, said hourly workers will make at least $10/hour in wages + tips combined starting Monday. now. Then vs.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: The Brew’s Weekly News Quiz: March 26
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Brew Mini: Hard Difficulty
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Brew Mini: Medium Difficulty
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Light Roast Is Dead, Long Live Sunday Edition
item.description: It will add a bunch of fresh sections to the Brew’s current lineup, including:A work advice columnAnalysis of a juicy news topicZillow surfingMeme contestInterviews with really cool peopleWhereas our daily newsletter is tied to the business news cycle like a tongue to a pole in winter, Sunday Edition will be free to roam and explore more general interest topics with a grounding in business. Sunday Edition will be available for everyone, which allows us to devote more resources to this newsletter and provide readers with top-tier content. But in the meantime, I want to share the basic structure of the new newsletter, give Light Roast a proper send-off, and explain why we decided to make the change.  Light Roast provided a fantastic space for us writers to connect with Brew readers on a more personal level, one that we will certainly miss. We are replacing Light Roast with a new reward.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Vaccine Tracker: March 27
item.description: At the current rate, the US would hit President Biden’s new goal of 200 million shots administered in his first 100 days. Moderna said earlier this month it had started testing its vaccine on kids.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Brew Mini: Easy Difficulty
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: WeWork Is Going Public Via SPAC
item.description: Now, WeWork is back up to a respectable $9 billion valuation. , to make its debut in the public markets, which have been waiting for WeWork like a prom date at the bottom of the stairs since 2019.  CEO Sandeep Mathrani expects WeWork to turn a profit by the end of this year, following some belt-tightening measures he made last summer. Now, flexible office space is back in demand, and WeWork 2.0 provides just that. WeWork is going public.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Germany Avoids “Baby Bust” With Rising Birth Rates
item.description: This jump in births runs counter to the current and even pre-pandemic fertility rates in the rest of Europe, the US, and other wealthy nations: There will be 300,000 fewer births this year in the US, according to estimates. No one’s totally sure, but some economists are pointing to Kurzarbeit, Germany’s state-funded safety net.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Dominion Voting Systems Files $1.6 Billion Lawsuit Against Fox News
item.description: And yesterday, lawyers for Dominion left the door open for going after individual Fox News broadcasters as well. Dominion Voting Systems ditched the Hawaiian shirt and khakis yesterday, instead filing a $1.6 billion lawsuit against Fox News.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 27
item.description: (Guernica)  Read: Your Saturday deep dive into the underworld of finch smuggling. The ship will probably remain stuck in the canal, blocking all traffic, until at least next week.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Spain Holds Rock Concert for 5,000 People in Covid Test
item.description: The concert was a government-sanctioned test to determine whether events in controlled settings could restart again without contributing to the spread of the coronavirus. Zoom out: Organizers said it was the biggest commercial event held in Europe since the pandemic began.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Ever Given, the Ship Stuck in the Suez Canal, Has Been Partially Refloated
item.description: Bottom line: If the Ever Given can fully break free today and allow traffic to pass, the shipping industry can avoid the worst scarring, according to the NYT. You can get deep about it.  The Ever Given, a mind-bogglingly huge container ship that’s been blocking the Suez Canal for almost a week, holding up an estimated $9.6 billion in goods a day, is way less stuck than it used to be.   But that hasn’t stopped everyone from having a little fun at the ship’s expense—okay, a lot of fun. The moon.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 29
item.description: (NYT Magazine) Read: An excellent discussion on genomic sequencing.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Week Ahead: March 29
item.description: Sports: The men’s and women’s college basketball tournaments roll on this week, and MLB’s Opening Day is Thursday. Jobs report: The Labor Department will drop employment numbers for March this Friday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Wall Street Mystery Swirls Over Massive Block Trades
item.description: A block trade is when huge amounts of shares trade hands, typically through negotiation outside of the open market to keep stock prices stable. Basically, what allegedly happened is that Archegos's lenders forced it to sell more than $20 billion worth of shares on Friday. In Saturday’s Brew, we noted that shares in Discovery and ViacomCBS had plunged on Friday following analyst downgrades.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 30
item.description: (The Atlantic)  Read: How mRNA technology could change the world.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Suez Canal is Cleared, but Blocks Effects Will Still Be Felt
item.description: Zoom out: The clog blocked more than 10% of global shipping traffic and brought up lots of talk about the fragility of global supply chains.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Lil Nas X and MSCHF Sneaker Collab is Making Everyone Mad
item.description: Zoom out: Lil Nas X timed the sneaker drop with his most recent music video release for “Montero (Call Me By Your Name),” the steamiest take on going to H-E-L-L we’ve ever seen.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Why Morning Brew Added Bitcoin to the Markets Section
item.description: We think our Markets section will be more relevant to readers with bitcoin in it. It's simply a recognition that finance, just like anything else, is changing, and our newsletter should reflect that. Perhaps you just took a tequila shot out of happiness. In their place, we added 1) bitcoin and 2) a "flex" spot, which will allow us to showcase any security—whether it's a tech stock, oil, or dogecoin—that made an interesting move the previous day.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: US Vaccine Progress Faces Off With Rising Caseloads
item.description: Onto the better newsOver one-third of adults (about 95 million people) have received at least one shot, according to the CDC. A lab leak was determined to be "extremely unlikely." In a draft report obtained by the AP, WHO researchers investigating the coronavirus said it most likely jumped from bats to another critter to humans. the latest installment in Covid-19: Origin Story.  + While we're here... Yesterday, Biden pleaded with state and local leaders to maintain or reinstate mask mandates as the rollout continues.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: NFTs: Frequently Asked Questions
item.description: And yes, you can make money off of an NFT by buying and reselling it for more.  An NFT is “a type of cryptographic token,” Emerging Tech Brew writer Ryan Duffy explains, but NFTs are different from cryptocurrencies because they’re not interchangeable.   When a digital asset goes on sale, you’re randomly chosen to buy it. Can I make money on it? One reason to buy an NFT is for its emotional value, which isn’t so different from physical objects... They buy it for the way it makes them feel. The same can be true for a GIF, image, video, or other digital asset.  On Top Shot for instance, you register to join a waitlist that can be thousands of NBA fans long. Defining the blockchain is a whole ‘nother can of worms that you can read about here.  How do you buy an NFT?
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Business Acronyms You Should Know: The Master Guide
item.description: DOJ: The Department of Justice enforces US laws and handles federal civil and criminal cases. In business-to-business (B2B), the product is for a corporate customer.  SEC: The Securities and Exchange Commission is a federal agency that regulates securities markets (securities = financial instruments like stocks and bonds) to protect investors. US agencies and regulatorsCDC: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; if you don't know this after a year of Covid…it is responsible for promoting public health at home and abroad, responding to infectious diseases, and researching threats to human health.   FTC: The Federal Trade Commission is responsible for enforcing consumer protection laws and civil antitrust law. ) The finance-y stuffIPO: An initial public offering is a way for companies to go from private → public and raise capital by selling shares to public investors on a stock exchange.  WHO: The World Health Organization is a UN agency focused on public health—monitoring risks, responding to emergencies, promoting universal healthcare, and setting international standards.  OECD: The Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development is an economic organization of 37 so-called "developed" nations. S&P: Standard & Poor's (now known as S&P Global) is an analytics and financial data corporation. 19 members are part of the common currency "eurozone,." In direct-to-consumer, companies like Warby Parker send their product straight to you. But, often, the business world can feel like a jumble of insider language and acronyms. ESG: Environmental, social, and governance is a framework that measures corporations' positions on issues like human rights, diversity, employee welfare, and climate impacts. It's one of the most widely used indicators of economic health. It's goal is to coordinate prices and keep oil markets stable. UI: User experience vs. It's goal is to promote economic development and global trade. CSR: Corporate social responsibility offers a model for businesses to have a positive impact on society and remain accountable not only to shareholders, but also to the public.
item.author: Alex Hickey
